p: It is imperative that future research on climate change and health be conducted with equity as a central tenet. Approaching climate and health research from this perspective means a deep consideration of upstream drivers of health outcomes, including systemic and structural factors, with a vision toward justice. In this way, researchers can look not just at race or socioeconomic status as the distinguishing factors that determine disparate health outcomes, but rather, the upstream policies and practices that have led to unequal burdens in particular groups. As there is a growing recognition that measures to adapt to climate change may sometimes be maladaptive and worsen inequity, it is all the more important that equity is centered in research and policy approaches to mitigate the health impacts of climate change [ 62].
